moves.1. e4: White starts out with the very solid 1. e4.
moves.1... Nf6: Black responds by preemptively taking out his knight with 1...Nf6? This blunder allows White to attack the Knight and take more central territory.
moves.2. e5 Nd5 3. d4: Taking even more central territory. White's advantage right now is decisive.
moves.3... c6 4. c4: Taking even more territory. Black's knight is feeling heavy pressure, and is nothing but a liability for Black at this point.
moves.4... Nb4 5. a3 g6: Realizing his knight was a major liability, Black smartly decides to sacrifice it.
moves.6. axb4 Qb6 7. Qd2 h5: Black initiates a kingside attack. Majorly behind in development and pieces, will it be successful?
moves.8. c5 Qc7 9. Bc4 Bh6 10. Qc2: A high-level move, allowing White's queen to supervise both bishops at once.
moves.10... Bg7: Instead of taking White's unblocked dark-square bishop, Black wisely blocks his own bishop.
moves.11. Nf3: Continuing development. Transition to a normal mainline is still possible.
moves.11... e6 12. Bg5 Rf8: Black moves his rook for no discernible reason.
moves.14. Qxg6+ Rf7 15. exf6 Bh8: Another major blunder, allowing White to force checkmate.
moves.16. Qg8+ Rf8 17. f7#: After a series of conditional moves, White wins the game.
